text: <p>That synthesis won't occur because of some bond strain. The bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane is able to perform up and down alternating axial and equatorial bonds where as the bicyclo[2.2.1] is not able to do so as the bridge disrupts that pattern. Therefore, this may cause some bond strain or make the location for the substitution not very accessible and cause a 0%. Although both locations make tertiary carbocations, situation B won't occur due to the strain caused by the disruption of the axial and equatorial bond patterns. </p>
<p>Your explanation has the same basic element as me but your explanation is much more complete. Actually make me understand details I didn't think of, thank you and great job!</p>

<p>Maybe because B has a lot of bond strain, so free radical not stable so less likely to form whereas A barely has any bond strain because it can bend to assume stable configuration so radical formed stabilized by hyperconjugation so likely to form</p>

<p>Radical halogenation mechanisms will always prefer the formation of a stable radical. The pathway in which the most stable radical is formed has the less amount of activation energy and is therefore preferred. In reaction A, the radical is located 100% of the time at the bridgehead, this makes sense as the bridgehead is 3prime and the "double boat-chair conformation" allows for potential rotations to reduce the amount of strain. However, in reaction B no such rotations are possible to stabilize the radical created at the bridgehead, it is under huge amounts of strain. Therefore the activation energy for this pathway is way higher and the reaction will not follow it. </p>
<p>Amazing answer Vivan</p>

<p>When bicyclo(3.3.1)nonane is treated with Br2 under irradiation, the bromine that substitutes the hydrogen is mostly in the equatorial position due to the chair flip conformations. Since bromine is a big atom, this allows for less interactions with the many other substituents that are close by. However, in bicyclo(2.2.1)heptane, there are no chair flip conformations, so the big bromine atom would have a lot of interaction with nearby substituents. Therefore, it is possible the reaction would not take place as the product would be too unstable compared to the reactant.</p>

<p>The bonds in bicyclo[2.2.1] heptane are already under a lot of strain because they are being held at angles much less than their ideal. The bridgeheads are under the most strain and so, attempting to make them a free radical is extremely unstable and would not be favoured. It is for this reason that we see 0% of the product being a bridgehead bromination. For the nonane, on the other hand, their bonds being held fairly close to the ideal angle and due to this, the tertiary radical that would be formed at the bridgehead carbon is very stable. </p>
<p>Love you answer! The visual aid with color-coding makes your conclusion very clear and easy to follow. Nice work :)</p>

<p>The substitution of Br onto the bridgehead involves the formation of a radical at the bridgeheads. Radicals typically prefer an sp2 planar geometry. The first structure A is capable of forming planar geometry because it is larger and more flexible. The second structure B is not capable of forming planar geometry at the bridgehead becasue its structure is very rigid. This is why Br will not substitute at the bridgehead of structure B because it is not favourable to form a radical. </p>
<p>I agree with your explanation, and I like how you explained the stability of the free radical in terms of bond angle. I did not consider this in my answer. Great job!</p>

<p>The bromination with light takes place via a radical mechanism. For a radical to be stable, it must be in a sp2 hybridized carbon intermediate and needs to be planar. In the compound B, the radical that will be formed will be unstable because it will be out of the plane.</p>

<p>In the Bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane, the radical intermediate is possible, because the two rings have two more carbons and therefore they are more flexible which will let the bridgehead go through a planar conformation to form an sp2 hybridized radical intermediate in order to undergo the substitution.</p>

<p>I would expect that this reaction would not take place because it is not energetically favorable. Its possible that the radical halogenation of the bicyclononane is exothermic whilst the the same reaction with the bicycloheptane is endothermic. These types of reactions do not typically take place if they require too much energy to get started.  </p>

<p>A has two cyclohexanes connected by a bridge, while B has two cyclopentanes connected by a bridge. The cyclohexane has less ring strain, so adding the Br presents less of a problem in terms of steric hindrance. While for cyclopentane, although it is very stable and doesn't want to add the Br because that could add steric hindrance, so it is not favored.</p>

<p>I think the reason for the observed phenomenon is due to strain in the rings. The C-C bonds on each end of Bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane are in right angles, so there is greater angular strain compared to in Bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane. This is important because there is an inverse relationship between strain and stability in cyclic alkanes. As Bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane experiences less strain, it is more stable and therefore forms a more stable radical. Hence substitution can take place with Br2. Conversely, Bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane is significantly less stable so it is not favorable to carry out the substitution reaction.</p>

<p>Since bicycle[3.3.1]nonane has larger bridges (loops) than bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane, this may allow the structure to make more conformations that can minimize stress (ie. repulsion and steric hinderances) that would be added by Br. </p>
<p>Clear explanation!</p>
<p>I had a similar idea to you but your explanation helped me understand the reasoning behind the answer better. Great job!</p>

<p>When the radical intermediates form, the hybridization of the carbons with the radicals go from sp3 to sp2. For the bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane, this new planar geometry causes extremely high amounts of ring and angle strain. This strain is too high for the radical intermediate to feasibly form and therefore substitution is not observed. However since the bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane has more carbons in the main ring, the amount of strain produced is far less. Because of this, substitution is observed for the bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane but not for the bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane. </p>

<p>It may be that in the first reaction, the reaction takes place at the bridgehead carbon due to the fact that pi-orbitals are aligned and are parallel to each other, making the reaction possible, however in the second structure, the 3-D view of the pi-orbitals show that they are perpendicular to each other, thus inhibiting the reaction from occurring as the bridgehead carbon is unstable  </p>

<p>A possible explanation to the bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane reacting and not the bicyco[2.2.1] is the ring strain in cyclopentane that is minimized in cyclohexane (due to the possible chair conformations). The bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane is formed of cyclohexane which has minimized ring strain allowing it to react with Br2 in the presence of light. While bicyclo[2.2.1] is formed of cyclopentane which has neighbouring carbons that causes some hindrances.</p>

This probably creates steric collisions that block Br2 from attacking an H atom, leading to the bromination.</p>

<p>The steric strain between the bromine substituent and the ring is more unfavourable in bicycloheptane where the downwards conformation of the ring impedes the reaction to occur at bridgeheads. Rather, bicyclononane's ring conformation allows for substitution because of the asymmetric upwards/downwards orientation on either side of the bridge. </p>

<p>The first molecule (A) is more flexible than the second one, therefore the radical can adopt a more stable configuration, leaving place for the bromine to attack it. In the B, the structure is too planar leaving no place for the bromine to attack the radical.</p>

<p>In bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane, bromination occurs through a radical mechanism. This is possible because the intermediate has a ring with two more carbons than bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane. That said, the bicyclo[3.3.1]heptane ring is much more flexible and the bridged carbon can go through planar intermediate conformation. This forms an sp2 hybridized radical intermediate to form the brominated product.</p>

<p>However, in bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane, a planar intermediate at the bridged carbon isn’t possible since that position is highly strained (lacking the two extra carbons) which prevents it from becoming planar. That said, the bromination does not occur because sp2 hybridization is not possible. </p>

<p>Since the bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane, is constituted of two cyclohexane rings, it is more stable (it has less ring strain) than bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane, which is constituted of 2 cyclopentane rings. The superior stability in the bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane will allow an hydrogen bond to be broken much more easily than in the bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane. Since bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane is already not very stable (it has high ring strain), breaking an hydrogen bond would make it even less stable, which is why it does not react with Br2 and light. </p>

<p>I'm not 100% sure, but my working idea is that in bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane, the ring is flexible and stabilizes the bridge head radical, due to both flexibility and the pi-orbital being in the same plane (see diagram for a visualization). I think this is because the 8 carbon ring is large enough for the bridging carbon to fit within the ring, thus allowing for the planar sp2 hybridization to form temporarily and for the radical carbon to be brominated. With the bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane, the six carbon ring is not large enough for the bridging carbon to fit within it. Thus, the carbon is stuck in its tetrahedral shape and it will not reacti with the bromine radical. (This is just a theory)</p>

<p>I assume that the reason has something to do with Bredt‘s Rule which stated that for a small ring bicyclic compound (less than 7 carbons), the bridgehead atom is extremely unstable and hardly isolated. So even the rule mainly refers to the double bone structure, but I think the radical intermediate shares some similar properties, and the rule still apply. In our case, due to the poor orbital overlap, the radical intermediate is too unstable and unable to be obtained and thus the second step of substitution will not pursue.</p>

<p>The substitution occurs on the bridgehead of A, but not B because of the structure's rigidity. Because B is more rigid than A, it most likely does not prefer going into sp2 hybridization to form a radical at the bridgehead (geometry has to be planar), whereas A has more flexibility from having more carbons. If radical cannot be formed, this type of bromination cannot occur, which is why I believe that this substitution does not occur on B. </p>

<p>Starting by SN1, we know that it needs the formation of a carbocation that needs a trigonal planar geometry but in this structure it can't happen since it is a trigonal pyramidal planar.</p>

<p>Also for SN2, we know that it only works on primary or secondary, but here we have a tertiary alkyl halide which makes it unreactive to SN2.</p>

<p>The second reaction does not occur because the ring is inflexible and will not allow the formation of a planar bridgehead. Therefore, no reaction will occur. However, in the first reaction, the ring has two more carbons. Thus, the bridgehead radical has added stability allowing the formation of a bridgehead. </p>
<p>Your explanation was very thorough and concise. Great job!!</p>

<p>Ideally, at the bridgehead, carbons should be tetrahedral to avoid a ring strain. Bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane is the compound having the least number of carbons (compared to B). Consequently, the molecule should have less ring strain. Indeed, in its chair conformation we could perceive tetrahedral carbons contributing to the stabilization of the structure. However, for bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane (compound with the highest number of carbons), bridgehead carbons have a smaller bond angle, resulting in a higher strain. As a consequence the structure is considered as being less stabilized and thus, more reactive. This is why molecule A is preferred to undergo a substitution reaction when treated with Br2 under irradiation.</p>

<p>Bromination under light occurs through a radical reaction mechanism. In order for a radical reaction to proceed, the intermediate must be sufficiently stable such that the Ea barrier is not too high. A stable radical intermediate would need to be planar and have sp2 hybridized carbons. For reaction B, this is not possible because the radical will be formed out of the plane. For reaction A, the formation of a radical intermediate is possible since each side of the carbon ring have enough carbons to allow for flexibility; this will permit the bridgehead to enter a planar conformation such that an sp2 hybridized, planar, radical intermediate can be formed, allowing for bromine substitution to occur.</p>

<p>There is no substitution observed at the bridgehead of bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane due to the angle strain and torsional strain in the molecule. Although the Br2 would want to react with a tertiary radical, there could be more strain due to the proximity of the larger groups on the symmetrical bicyclo structure. Also since bromine is a less reactive agent and more stereoselective than another halogens, like chlorine, it could affect the placement of the substitution. </p>

<p>Not entirely sure. It may be due to B being symmetrical and therefore the addition of the Br group would create too much bond stain on the product. Additionally, it could be that Br is just not reactive enough to react with molecule B if it's stable. </p>

<p>Both of these reactions are called radical halogenations because, in the presence of light, the alkanes within these 2 compounds are able to form alkyl halides. Substitution by Br2 and light on Bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane gives us 100% of a product because Br can better extract a hydrogen atom from the alkane C-H bonds. This will increase the yield of reaction with compound A.</p>

<p>In addition, the bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane has a lot of bond strain, so the free radicals are unstable. Therefore there is less likelihood for it to form whereas bicylco[3.3.1]nonane barely has any bond strain due to its stability. </p>
<p>Great Job. I liked how you used a clear diagram to explain your ideas</p>

<p>The configuration of the bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane presents two conformations. The chair conformations have no ring straIn on them and therefore are the most stable conformation with the lowest energies. In comparison the bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane has ring strain and is not as stable as structure A. The mechanism described involves the formation of a radical. Due to the fact that structure A is stable, the radical intermediate can form however because structure B exhibits strain the radical is very unstable and therefore the product does not form. </p>

<p>in structure A, bromination occurs at the bridged carbon due to the pressure from the pi orbital in the same plane. Therefore, substitution can take place. </p>

<p>in structure B, the carbocation formation would be unstable at the bridged carbon. The instability is due to the the pi orbital perpendicular to the plane. Therefore, no substitution can occur. </p>

<p><strong>The conformation of the bicyclo[3.3.1]nonane is much more stable than the one of the bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane. <p>The Br substitution can occur on structure A because structure A is less sterically hindered than structure B. Since structure A is nonane, it has a bigger bicyclo structure; in other words, the carbons are more spread out. <p>In bromination with light, there will be radical intermediate. The stability of this radical intermediate will determine if the reaction will follow through. However, molecule B is not able to do that because it is formed out of the plane. </p>

<p>In order to figure out the different outcomes, we have to observe both concerned structures : A and B. The only difference between these two molecules is the number of carbon atoms per ring : nine versus seven. However, they are similar in the sense that the ring contains solely carbon atoms. We can then understand that when we have carbon rings, as the atoms are closer to each other, there is the presence of steric hindrance between the atoms. And as we have more carbon atoms, we have more internal steric hindrance. With this being said, as A has more atoms per ring than B, it has increased steric hindrance, which means it is less stable, and therefore more reactive, which is why it can undergo bromine substitution.</p>

<p>Through radical halogenation, in the presence of light, Br2 will dissociate to form halide radicals. The halide radical can then abstract a hydrogen atom from the alkane, leaving behind a carbon radical. Hypothetically, this will occur at the bridgeheads of these molecules because they are 3˚ carbons, this will form the most stable radical through hyperconjugation. The carbon radical then attacks Br2 and forms a C-Br sigma bond. For this to occur the carbon atom must be sp2 and planar. When bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane (B) is treated with Br2 under irradiation, no substitution takes place at the bridgehead because the ring is rigid and cannot become planar. However, A is a larger molecule and has more flexibility so it can become planar at the bridgehead so substitution is possible.</p>

<p>For A, there is enough hyper conjugation to stabilize a radical, compared two B. For B, It would be more stable for the bridge to break and form a double bond with the methyl group the bridge is attached two as the geometry of the structure of B is not suffice for hyper conjugation. While structure A has both more carbons and a ringed structure which greatly increase the stability of a radical, allowing Br to be able to be added.</p>
